Activity: Log in to the system, check emails and company announcements. Skim through relevant articles on game server architectures and security best practices for inspiration.

Begin outlining the server architecture document. Focus on identifying key components like authentication, game session management, and data persistence. Note down potential technologies (e.g., Node.js, Go, Java) and their pros/cons for our specific game.

Research different database options (SQL vs. NoSQL) considering the type of data we'll be storing (player profiles, game state, etc.). Evaluate performance characteristics and scalability for each option. Start drafting a preliminary database schema.

Continue working on the database schema, focusing on player data. Define tables/collections for user accounts, character information, inventory, and stats.  Consider relationships between these entities.

Resume working on server architecture, detailing the communication flow between client and server. Start designing the API endpoints required for player authentication, game state updates, and other essential functionalities.

Draft API specifications for player authentication (login, registration). Consider security measures like password hashing and token-based authentication.  Note: Need to consult @cdev-1 and @cdev-2 regarding client-side integration requirements. Email @cdev-1 @cdev-2 regarding API conventions.

Continue detailing the server architecture document, focusing on game session management. Outline how game sessions will be created, managed, and terminated. Address concurrent player limits and matchmaking considerations.
Wrap up the day by consolidating notes and organizing the server architecture document.  Review potential technologies and database options. Briefly search on potential anti-cheat implementations.
